[Mr Speaker in the Chair]

SINGAPORE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS (TEMPORARY

PROVISIONS) (NO. 2) BILL



    Order read for resumption of debate on Question [19th December, 1963], "That the Bill be now read a Second time.".

    Question again proposed.

2.31 p.m.

    Mr Speaker: The Deputy Prime Minister was speaking in reply yesterday when he was interrupted at the moment of interruption. Does the Deputy Prime Minister wish to speak further?

    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Just one line. Mr Speaker, I was going to end yesterday rebutting the Member for Hong Lim who had earlier on suggested that there was an attempt by the Government to fiddle with the electoral registers. I would only like to remind him that the results of the elections depend upon those who cast votes themselves. They are human beings who must be present in person. And being human beings, they will not like, without their own consent, to be transferred from one electoral district to another. Therefore, it is not possible at all to fiddle with the electoral registers to anybody's particular advantage. It is not the electoral registers which decide victory or defeat for a candidate, but

Column: 1050

it is the electorate themselves who make the decision.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole Assembly.

    Assembly immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. -[Dr Toh Chin Chye]

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

Column: 1050

SINGAPORE LEGISLATIVE ASSEMBLY ELECTIONS

(AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

2.36 p.m.

    Dr Toh Chin Chye: Mr Speaker, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    This amendment Bill is being introduced partly in the light of experience that has been acquired by the Elections Office over the past years. As the list of claimants after the register of electors and Lists A and B have been exhibited to the public has increased enormously from about 9,000 in 1959 to 22,500 in 1963, more time is now required for the registration of these claimants. This is provided for in clause 2 of the Bill.

    Clause 3 proposes an amendment to reduce the period between the date of issue of the Writ of Election and Nomination Day from nine days to five days. I would like to point out that this is in accord with the practice in the United Kingdom where from the time the Returning Officer receives the Writ up to the Day of Nomination, the period can be calculated to be about five days. In the United Kingdom, however, this period of five days is the maximum and cannot be increased by statute, whereas in Singapore the provision which we are asking now of five days should be the minimum period and this period could be increased to more than five days, if at any time it is desired to do so.

Column: 1051



    The amendment in clause 4 is consequential to the amendment in clause 3 if this is accepted. It seeks to reduce the period between the publication of the Notice of Election by the Returning Officer and Nomination Day from five days to four days. This is in line with the reduction of the period between the date of issue of the Writ of Election and Nomination Day as proposed in clause 3. The number of days between the Notice of Election by the Returning Officer and Nomination Day can be calculated to be the same as in the United Kingdom. It is considered that the publication of the notice by the Returning Officer at least four clear days before Nomination Day is sufficient notice to prospective candidates.

    Clause 5 suggests removing the limitation in the present Ordinance which stipulates that Polling Day shall be a Saturday. There is, in fact, no justification for this limitation at all. There has been some doubt as to whether Polling Day being a holiday should or should not be counted for purposes of determining the minimum number of days required between the publication by the Returning Officer of the notice of contested elections and Polling Day. This amendment is for the purpose of clearing that doubt.

    The amendments proposed in clause 6 follow the provision in the National Referendum Ordinance, which are necessary to ensure that on Polling Day there is no canvassing or undue influence exercised on electors who should be allowed to consider the platform of the various political Parties and candidates and vote according to their best judgment and free will.

    The intention of clause 7 is to prohibit secret society gangsters who are under Police Supervision Order from taking part in any election activity.

    Finally, clause 8 empowers the Returning Officer to use free of charge as a Polling Station any school or portion thereof for the purposes of any election. In the past it has been found that on occasions persons who were in charge of the premises of certain private

Column: 1052

schools were reluctant to allow the Returning Officer to use the schools as polling stations. Although the amendment empowers the Returning Officer to use such schools as polling stations, the power will not be exercised except in places where no other suitable building or place where a temporary building could be erected can be found. This applies mainly to the crowded city area where it is difficult to find suitable alternative buildings or vacant sites for temporary buildings to serve as polling stations.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question proposed.

    Mr Ong Lian Teng (Bukit Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, in regard to this Singapore Legislative Assembly Elections (Amendment) Bill introduced by the P.A.P. I have great doubts as to the true practice of parliamentary democracy. I fear that they want to resort to legal means to put into effect their dictatorial measures.

    The scope of democracy is still being limited by this Bill. Originally the period between the issue of Writ of Elections and Nomination Day was nine days. It is now the desire of the Government to reduce it to five days. To the Party in power, of course, there will be no difficulty or inconvenience, but to the Opposition Parties there will be great difficulty and hardship because all the disadvantages of the reduction of the period fall on the Opposition Parties.

    The Writ of Elections is issued by the Party in power, and not by any Opposition Party. Therefore, only the Party in power know when they are going to issue the Writ. So their intention is not to let the Opposition know or to have enough time to prepare for elections. Even in the recent general elections, the period was nine days from Nomination Day to Polling Day. So the total period would be two weeks from the issue of Writ of Elections to Polling Day. This period of two weeks is insufficient to Opposition Parties because they have to carry out election work,

Column: 1053

such as printing publicity material, the choice of candidates and election campaigning. But to the Party in power this is not so, because they know it in advance. I heard that publicity and propaganda material had, long before the general election was held, been printed in Hong Kong. They are in a position to know the date of any pending election and could take advantage of it. We in the Opposition do not have that advantage. We are put at a disadvantage. Of course, the Party in power can argue that they have fighters and that we too have fighters. Therefore, they say it is fair. In actual fact, it is not so. The Party in power is in control of all publicity and propaganda machinery. They can, therefore, carry on a propaganda campaign on a long-term basis for the elections. They do this, of course, through the Press, the radio and television. Their candidates will not be arrested by anybody. The Party in power can abuse their power by arresting prospective candidates who are in the Opposition. There is clear and concrete evidence to show this. Many of our prospective candidates were arrested prior to the general elections. This caused great difficulty to our Party.

    The P.A.P. can, of course, argue that the Government have still afforded us the opportunity and facilities to take part in the general elections, and that we are free to carry on with our propaganda work like the holding of mass rallies. But we are only afforded such opportunities during the period of nine days allowed to us. We are not afforded such opportunities or facilities on other days.

    Another aspect of this Bill is this. Clause 6 gives strong powers to the police. This provision is similar to the one in the Singapore National Referendum Ordinance of 1962. This clause provides that no person can, on Polling Day, enter two houses or places of work of the electors in the same polling district other than his own home. If

Column: 1054

he is seen doing that, he will be committing an offence under the provisions of this Bill, unless he can prove to the contrary. It also gives the Commissioner of Police very great powers in dealing with these matters. The police can enter and search any premises or place for the purpose of ascertaining whether such an offence is being committed. The P.A.P. may abuse these powers when applying these provisions. People will be intimidated. This provision will create fear in the electors. When we consider all the provisions of this Bill, we can see that Polling Day will be a day of terror when these rules are applied. This will be so if we take into consideration the provisions in clause 3. For instance, a hawker will he prohibited from carrying on his trade on Polling Day according to the provisions of this clause. This is because he is not allowed to enter more than two houses. Even those people who want to call on their friends will be committing an offence if they do so. Hawkers and shop assistants who wish to deliver their goods will have to enter more than two houses, but this will be construed as having committed an offence. Nobody will dare to go anywhere.

    In addition to this, it is the practice of the P.A.P. to intimidate and coerce people, by propaganda and other means, saying that if they carry on certain activities or take part in election campaigns, they will be arrested. There is thus an atmosphere of terror. There will be a reduction in the period from nine days to five days in regard to the period between the issue of the Writ of Elections and Nomination Day. We can see from this whether or not the P.A.P. are dictatorial. This shows that the P.A.P. have ignored the principles of democracy in the interest of the Party. I think democracy is the monopoly of the P.A.P. They can pass unreasonable and undemocratic laws in this House. After that they implement the laws outside this Assembly. They then turn round and say that they are doing things in accordance with the laws passed in this House. As a matter of fact, they are doing things contrary to the

Column: 1055

principles of democracy. This is not justice as embodied in the term "democracy". If they want to achieve their aim by this kind of legislation, then I advise them to introduce a Bill in this House whereby they can deprive others of any right. They have a majority in this House. They can also turn round and say that they have that right under the law. If they wish to be so undemocratic, they might as well pass a law to say that the victims of a robbery are guilty and the robbers are innocent. It is entirely wrong in principle for the P.A.P. to legislate laws from the point of view of their Party's interest.

    Mr Chow Chiok Hock (Ulu Pandan)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I believe you will agree with me that an election is a special feature in a democratic country. It is a peaceful method by which the people can express their wish. The people can decide the future of their country through the ballot box. I would like to tell the Back-benchers that whether the Opposition Members have enough time for propaganda or not does not depend on the number of days allowed for electioneering. Whether a candidate of the Opposition is good or bad will depend on what he has done in the past. A candidate cannot convince the people that he is good during the few days allowed for electioneering. Whether he is good or bad will depend on what he has done over a long period of time. They have complained that we have not given them enough time to carry out their election campaign in the rural areas. Voting is secret and the choice of a candidate is determined in a free manner. There is no humbug about it. Nobody can force another person to vote for a certain candidate. If one says that the voters can be made use of during the election to bring victory to another Party, then I say, in my view, this is impossible. Nobody will ever be used or will agree to any interference of their freedom. Canvassing actually is a method by which interference of this nature is effected. This was done by the Barisan Sosialis during the last election. That is why they were able to win a few seats.

Column: 1056

Their own candidates had to resort to canvassing and other illegal means. For example, the Member for Bukit Merah had not intended to stand for election in his constituency. But a few days before Nomination Day, a few leading figures of the Barisan Sosialis were sent to his house in order to persuade him to stand for election. They promised him certain conditions in the event of a Barisan victory. They threatened him by saying that should he refuse to stand for election, his position in Nanyang University would be made untenable. This is what they did. I personally feel that if we really want to safeguard the democratic system and the rights of the people, then we must give sufficient powers to the police to protect the rights and security of the people. But the Communists will always make use of the democratic system to undermine the system itself. That is to say, they are making use of democracy to undermine democracy itself. We hope that through the provisions of this Bill, the true spirit of democracy will be safeguarded and maintained. This will ensure that those who act foolishly and in the dark will not be able to do so again in the future.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak (Tampines)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, we have different kinds of elections. We have democratic elections as well as dirty and filthy elections. There are elections which are carried out fairly and justly and there are elections which are rigged. [Interruption] The Member for Jalan Besar does not know of a story of a King who was elected by the people. I will tell him. In the 19th century, Napoleon II of France made a law to force the people of France to elect him as a King and he received a hundred per cent votes. Does the Member know about this? If he does not know it, he should go and read his history books. [Interruption]

    Mr Speaker: Order. Will the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs allow the Member for Tampines to proceed? The Member for Tampines is now telling us stories which do not appear to be relevant to this Bill.

Column: 1057

I know the Member was led into it by interruptions. But please get on with the debate.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I was just saying that there are all kinds of elections. But it does not mean that an election is and can represent the true spirit of democracy. If an election is conducted fairly and justly, of course, we cannot deny that it is a democratic election. But if an election is done in a filthy way and is a humbug, then it is a dictatorial election. So one must not say that because in the last general election the P.A.P. obtained 37 seats, then it must be a democratic election.

    There is a peaceful election and a violent election. I think they had better listen to me carefully and quietly. What is the difference between a violent election and a peaceful election? My friends opposite must pay attention to what I am going to say. If you have basic common knowledge and common sense, you will recall that in the recent elections in South Korea and Japan, voters were forced to take part in the elections, and many of them were slaughtered and killed in these two places. Here in Singapore, similar incidents occurred in which Barisan Sosialis workers were assaulted. Can you say this was a peaceful election? Can you say it was conducted in a peaceful manner? There should be an election in which the voters can express their views freely. But in certain circumstances force was used on the voters. Violence too was used. So let them stop talking about the last election and claim that it was a peaceful election. I must say that the last election and future elections will not be conducted freely because of the number of days for campaigning which has been reduced from 9 to 5.

    Reference was made about the Member for Bukit Merah. Who was actually guilty of deception? It was not the Barisan Sosialis. Who was guilty of intimidation? It was the P.A.P. and the

Column: 1058

Prime Minister. We already know how the intimidation was done ---

    The Minister for National Development (Mr Lim Kim San): On a point of order. We are talking about this Elections Bill. We are not talking about what has happened. We do not want to listen to the figment of imagination of the Opposition of what happened.

    Mr Speaker: It is true, Mr Minister. What the Member for Tampines is doing is replying to an allegation made by the Member for Ulu Pandan about the election in Bukit Merah. Surely he has a right to reply.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, I am not aware that the Member for Ulu Pandan did that.

    Mr Speaker: He did that. The Member for Ulu Pandan cast some aspersions on the election in Bukit Merah. Please continue, Mr Poh.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): I think the Minister must behave himself ---

    Mr Speaker: Order. All that the Minister was doing was to come up on a point of order, which is very proper. The Member should not make any allegations against the Minister.

    Mr Lim Kim San: Improper allegations.

    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I am sorry. I asked him not to be excited. I did not mean to say that he must behave himself. I asked him to be calm and not to be excited. That was what I meant ---

    Mr Lim Kim San: Mr Speaker, the Member is taking advantage of your ignorance of the Chinese language. I think he was just fooling around because what he said was "Luan, Luan lai", which means "rubbish". Now he turns round and says that what he said was "slowly, slowly".

    Mr Speaker: Please proceed. No more references to the Minister. Get on to the subject.

Column: 1059



    Mr Poh Ber Liak(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I just do not understand whether our Member for Bukit Merah has authorised the Member opposite to speak on his behalf, or whether the Barisan Sosialis Headquarters have given authority to the Members opposite to make reports to this House about the candidature of the Member for Bukit Merah. I just do not understand at all, it appears that our rights as a Party and the Party's internal affairs and decisions made by the Party were made in consultation with Members opposite. I just do not understand why he should smear our Member for Bukit Merah. It looks as though he is jealous of our success in Bukit Merah.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Health (Mr Sia Kah Hui): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Tampines is quite a historian. He has given us a list of the various types of elections. But I think he has forgotten one particular type. Does he know there is one great country, a big country where, during election time, there is only a single list of candidates and no one ever loses? Everyone wins! That is the kind of country that he admires. I should remind him that there is only one Party candidate and no one else. But maybe he prefers that one. When they talk about elections being undemocratic and so on, well, for propaganda purposes, it is all right. But when it comes to actual fact, when they were talking about the defeat of Mr Lee Khoon Choy in Bukit Panjang, they never said a word that the last election was undemocratic. They even thought that it was a wonderful election that they had won in Bukit Panjang.

    It is said that to reduce the number of days will benefit the Government Party by giving it time to prepare well in advance. Any political Party that is worth its salt and has got a platform would surely have prepared everything in readiness a long time beforehand. Yes, all these years, in fact; every day is part of a politician's work. There is no last-minute juggling about. That is why I say that he is thinking only of presenting candidates at the last minute

Column: 1060

and trying to pull the wool over the eyes of the electorate in a last-minute effort.

    When the Member was talking on the point that on election day the police will have the power to check canvassing and so on and talking about shop assistants going round - "ch'u ch'i sung hoa" - I wonder whether he was thinking that there is one way out. Policemen are wise enough, and I think they have a sufficiently fair standard of education to differentiate between a canvasser and a shop assistant. But I can say here is one way out. If he thinks that being a shop assistant he can get away from this part of the Bill, where policemen will not allow a man to go to more than two or three places on canvassing day, well, he can disguise himself as a shop assistant and get away with it.

    During the last election, the complaint was that the number of days for campaigning was too short and all the rest of it, but I am sure that if there were more time, if we were able to refute some of the statements that Mr Tan Lark Sye had said, perhaps some of these gentlemen would not be in this Chamber today.

    The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Seng)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, I feel this amendment Bill is full of the spirit of democracy. As a matter of fact, the aim of the amendment will act in the same manner on the Party in power as well as on the Opposition Parties. The reduction of nine days to five days is to enable officers of the Elections Department to prepare themselves for Nomination Day. It is not our intention to make use of the provisions to restrict the activities of all the political Parties in their contact with the electorate. No, it is not our intention. If the Barisan can claim that they have the support of the broad masses behind them, then why should they be afraid of when and where election is to be conducted? Why should they be afraid and worry about the number of days allowed for campaigning? They just cannot say that there is no democracy because the number of days is reduced. If they claim

Column: 1061

that they are the heroes of the people, they are the representatives of the people, they have no reason to fear at all. But it is surprising that their remarks against this Bill show that they are paper tigers and paper heroes. They really do not have the support of the people, and that is why they are afraid of this Bill, which will give the Government the power to hold elections at any time. Then they will be afraid.

    Mr Speaker, as I have said just now, this amendment Bill is full of the spirit of democracy, because we have no intention and desire to restrict the opportunities of the Opposition Members to come into contact with the electorate. In the last five years of our office, we have given them opportunities to come into contact with the people. In fact, they did make use of these opportunities to spread rumours among the electorate and the people. The Members opposite are really good at spreading rumours. They made the allegation that our propaganda material was printed in Hong Kong, but I can prove to them that it was published and printed by our local printers. But it is the usual tactic of the Barisan Sosialis to spread rumours. They say the rumours are spread by others but, in fact, they came from them. So we can see that the Barisan Sosialis, who claim to be heroes of the people and enjoy the support of the people, are really humbugs. If they really had the support of the people and they had five years to carry out their propaganda work, then they should not have been what they are now. They would have got the support of the people and come to power. What difference does it make between nine days and five days? Do you mean to say that the reduction of the number of days is going to affect the Opposition to such an extent as to warrant the uncalled for criticism against the Bill?

    Then they spoke about the election of a king. I would like to ask them what is the meaning of the word "election"? Election means competition. In this historical case that they referred to, was there another candidate competing for

Column: 1062

the throne? No. That was not so. That being so, where was the election? They are just talking nonsense. Their talk is very preposterous and absurd. If it was a true election, of course, there must be another person competing for the same thing. If there was a true election for a king, then there must be another candidate competing with Napoleon for the throne. But from the Member's own historical knowledge - let us assume that he has some such knowledge - he knows that there was no candidate competing with Napoleon for the throne. Can you call that an election for a king?

    They say that the P.A.P. are not democratic and that their workers were assaulted during the election. Now let us look at them. They are all very young and have strong muscles.

    Mr Speaker: Order. The hon. Member is making a personal attack. Will he leave the "young Members" - as he calls them alone? Please get on with the debate.

    Mr Chan Chee Seng(In Mandarin): I am just making a point to refute their allegation that their workers were assaulted and hit on the head during the election. I say that their people were not so peaceful and innocent. We saw how lorry-loads of their supporters went round prepared for a fight at any moment. How could such people have been assaulted? Who will believe their allegation that it was the P.A.P. people who assaulted the Barisan boys? If this was so, I am sure the P.A.P. would not have been returned with 37 seats. If we had done so, we would have resorted to violence against our opponents and they would not have had a chance to come in here at all. It was fortunate that the P.A.P. did not restrict the activities of the Barisan Sosialis during the election. In fact, we gave them ample opportunities to conduct their election campaign in a democratic manner so that the people could make a free choice of their candidates. The facts have proved that we are right. The people have chosen us again. And yet they talk of the broad masses behind them. But it was the broad masses who objected to their coming to power.

Column: 1063

Where was the support that they had? If they say that the people were behind them, then the people would have voted them in. But why did they choose such a handful of them? On the other hand, why were 37 of us elected? We have been here day in and day out continuously explaining to them, and yet they fail to understand the true position. These people just refuse to understand the fact that Singapore has joined Malaysia as a State. Instead of referring to our country as Malaysia, they still use the term "Malaya". [Interruption]

    Mr Speaker, Sir, there is one other point I wish to draw attention to, and that is with regard to the police. They say that during the election the police were given power to arrest the Barisan people and to interfere with the activities of the workers and delivery-clerks, thereby creating an atmosphere of fear. This is sheer falsehood in order to divert the attention and blind the vision of the people. We know that the police do not belong to the P.A.P. They do not belong to any Party. They are a neutral force and are above party politics. They are not a partisan force. If you are guilty of an offence, then the police will arrest you. If you want to sell out the interests of the country and become traitors, then, of course, the police will arrest you. What else do you expect the police to do? If you do not have the consent of the members of a union and you make use of the funds, then, of course, the police will investigate into the matter. But the Barisan Members have the cheek to say that the police are helping the P.A.P. Mr Speaker, Sir, you appreciate that the police are above politics and are neutral. If you are guilty of any offence, you will have to face the law. This is a State where the rule of law prevails. [Interruption]

    Mr Speaker: Order.

    Mr Kow Kee Seng (Paya Lebar)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Member for Ulu Pandan referred to the Member for Bukit Merah. It is lucky that he said that in this House. If he had said it outside this House, we would have taken court action against him.

Column: 1064

But his allegation does not merit our rebuttal.

    I wish to touch on the points raised by the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs. He said there were no rival candidates competing with Napoleon for the throne. But Napoleon also said that he was elected by the people. For example, the ex-President of South Korea, Syngman Rhee, was also elected by the people in a democratic way. There was a rival candidate. But sometimes such rival candidates are arrested, executed or they just disappear in elections.

    The Parliamentary Secretary also made another point. He said that if we have mass support, we can take part in elections anywhere and at any time. But in the recent election, one of our candidates, Mr Tan Siew Swee, was arrested just before Nomination Day. Mr Speaker, Sir, this was the so-called election referred to by the Parliamentary Secretary. We know that once a candidate is arrested and detained, he cannot take part in the election.

    I am now going to refer to the election in Sarawak. That was also an election. The Opposition Parties in Sarawak also nominated their candidates to contest the election, but they were arrested by the police and detained in a police station far away from the town. Later on, they were released and asked to walk home.
